explanation: To check the MISRA rule about pointing-to const, you must know the exact parameter types and behaviors of the callees that receive the pointer 'params_str' (and any pointer they forward). The immediate callee process_short_param: its prototype determines whether it accepts a const char * or a plain char * or otherwise writes through the pointer. If it forwards the pointer to any of the lower-level handlers, those handlers' prototypes (the listed process_param__* functions) determine whether the pointed-to data can be const-qualified. If any callee accepts a non-const char * or performs writes through the buffer, the const qualification on params_str would be inappropriate; if all accept const char * and do not write, params_str should remain or be made const. Therefore include the declarations/definitions (signatures and any write semantics) for process_short_param and all process_param__* functions so the next analyser can determine whether the pointee type can (or cannot) be const-qualified.
